column1: Which cricket team will win the 2021 ICC World Test Championship Final?
column5: ['India', 'New Zealand', 'The match will end in a draw or tie', 'The 2021 Final will either be canceled or the first day will be postponed until after 18 July 2021']
column6: ['Sports']

Weather has taken a turn for the worse, but doesn’t on the website I use which I find more reliable than the Met Office (stopped using them years ago) says rain tomorrow morning and lunchtime, so unless outfield is a mess then probably won’t lose all day. And while there is rain in most days it looks more showery than set in https://www.meteoblue.com/en/weather/week/southampton_united-kingdom_2637487

Although Friday will be lost to rain if the Met Office is right, I think the rest of the test will be relatively unaffected, so there's much more likelihood of a result than I thought a few days ago. https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/weather/forecast/gcp185f25#?date=2021-06-22

Revising to make the draw (slightly) more likely. The weather forecast is pretty poor throughout, and having read the WTC playing conditions (well, some of the 98 pages), overs can only be made up for interruptions (not slow over rates - DO NOT GET ME STARTED!). That said, it might be a rather stop/start affair, which might make it a little more difficult for the batsmen, so the draw is not as high a chance as it might be. The weather also suggests despite recent dry weather, there might be a bit of early assistance for the seam bowlers on Friday morning if the pitch is sweating under the covers. The Rose Bowl is historically one of the better grounds for spin, so NZ might have a tricky decision if they were to win the toss if there is a lot of cloud cover and rain in the air. One curious thing - if Friday is a complete washout, is the game still considered a 5d test? With the reserve day? The reason this matters is if it becomes a 4d game, the follow on is 150 not 200, which might impact the draw %. Tenuous perhaps. Either way, looking forward to the game.

I had a feeling in my bones from the onset that weather might be a problem, this time of year and despite the extra day added there will be a fair amount of play lost. Have to agree with @DylanWilliams that NZ would handle these conditions better, also their bowling has good against England
Due to weather forecast of persistent rain. If there is much play, I imagine NZ better equiped to deal with it. Could rain totally cancel it? - probably not, but just increasing it from zero

Weather forecast now has a good chance of Friday 18th being washed out ("heavy rain") and showers at least on 3 more days... so I'm pushing my draw likelihood back up. Also dropping cancellation/postponement option to near zero as we are just one day away now and even though the covid situation has deteriorated slightly in the UK (lifting of lockdown restrictions delayed by a month) I can't see it getting bad enough quickly enough for this option to really be in play for that reason.
Weather still looks very unsettled during the window for this game (I'm sure I've read that it is scheduled to run from the 18-22nd, but the 23rd is a spare day if they need it). Upping my Draw %
The odds have moved significantly to price in a draw. I’m humbling slightly.
reduced probability of cancel or postponement to below 1 in 100 (that would be a zero then...) NZ betting agency (NZTAB) has a draw sitting favourite at the moment.

very unlikely it will go ahead. They seem evenly matched so have upped the probability that it will end in a draw (although i am not sure of the rules around this). I don't know much about the Indian team :-(
New Zealand have a better pace attack and have been playing in England already for some time, so going to be better prepared for the conditions.

Match starts on Friday 18th June in Southampton. Weather forecast for that day is heavy rain, some rain forecast on Sunday-Wednesday as well. Teams are evenly matches so should not be a quick victory either way, so prospect of regular rain increases chances of a draw. NZ played very well in winning the 2 match series this month in England. They will be ready and confident as long as the weather doesn't intervene too much.
Dropped NZ a bit and raised a draw World cricketing personalities are mainly calling it close. Betting agencies are giving very close odds

NZ slight favourites as they are most naturally suited to English conditions, and are in good form, having just beat England in England. However India boast the stronger starting XI which makes this a very close contest. Draw is therefore another strong possibility. More information on playing conditions (mainly weather, pitch) will be needed to adjust predictions.
The weather forecast from Thursday onwards is dreadful, with high chances of rain for the duration of all six days of the match so the draw must be in contention again.

It's a two-horse race so reluctant to boost NZ's chances too much higher but the signs are good for NZ. Beat England with some key players missing? Check. Come through without major injury concerns? Check. COVID seemingly under control? Check. Even the weather looks like it will favour NZ: some showers, sure, but enough time to play out a result. Damp, overcast conditions will have the swing bowlers licking their lips.
based on NZ form in UK and weather forecast

Really solid performance from NZ, especially from a batting perspective. England bowled reasonably well in home conditions, but NZ still managed competitive (or better) totals in both tests. Hard to read too much into the bowling performance in the second test given the debacle that was the England 2nd innings. Patel is a better spinner than Santner, BUT not sure he will cause the Indian batsmen too many problems in English conditions. My view is still largely skewed by NZ getting 2 test matches as practise (although for some it's one test - Williamson, Watling, Southee). It is not inconceivable for India to bat first and have a bad first morning and make it very hard.

Did a bit more thinking about the weather... average of 7.7 days with precipitation (>= 1 mm) in Southampton in June, so about 25% of the days in the month. So could expect just over 1 day with precipitation during the scheduled five days of the match. Given the reserve day and the low draw rate for teams these days I'm happy to pull the draw likelihood back to 5% now. Plus we are now close enough to see a weather forecast, and according to the UK Met Office it looks OK for the first two days.

It’s close. NZ looking good and getting some good practice in against England. But England play very differently to India. Not a lot of spin from England and will be from India. But India haven’t played in a England. My views keep veering wildly so have to split it.

India has not had much practice time, first full team outing was yesterday. Blackcaps have been able to rest a few bowlers for the second english test. NZ TAB odds have turned around to NZ slight favourites Weather looking good
Long term weather forecast is good for Southampton

Ok, I’ve going even stevens. NZ against England in 1st test showed good swing, which India aren’t that great with. But weather and pitch showed that spin may be coming into play. Dry phase in UK due to high pressure, and looks like might stick a couple of weeks. That will dry the pitch and mean more spin. How they prep the pitch used will also be interesting. For a neutral game they will prep different than if it’s an England game. Despite country cricket being good for seam will the test strip be prepped the same?
Less likely it will be postponed, nz practice games vs England
adjusting for time being so close now.
As the temporal window shrinks the chance of covid-related postponement reduces. Am reallocating this between draw (weather) and India... can't bring myself to push NZ above 50%!
A draw is on the cards with weather interruption. India has no recent match practice?? NZ does but batting is erratic and bowling a bit 1D no decent spinner
Chance of cancellation/postponement diminishing...11 days to go, Hampshire County is below average in UK for new cases, both teams have arrived and are "bubbled."
NZs lower middle order does worry me a little.

Without knowledge of cricket, I will follow the main comments on sports websites. It seems that it is going to be a very even match. Some see India as the favorites, but, on the other hand, the weather and having played two Test matches before the final may favor NZ.
Updating to a lower chance that the final will be cancelled or have the first day postponed as NZ black caps is in England and their match against England is going ahead.

NZ have arrived in England ahead of a two test series vs England (both before the Championship final). This should mean they are better acclimitised and ready for the condition of English pitches. Third Covid wave probably underway in UK now so that's why I'm not reducing the chance of cancellation much just yet. Game could proceed with no spectators if need be?

Weather has turned nicer in UK, won’t dry the ground out but potentially could make for better playing conditions. But it’s got to last another 3 weeks yet. However if the weather pattern gets stuck like it did as cold and wet for May, then it could end up being perfect playing conditions. And, without ever getting the technicalities of this, I get the impression it might be really food for swing. That favours NZ in both batting and bowling. India have struggled a bit with swing.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/may/31/end-of-england-covid-lockdown-on-21-june-increasingly-in-doubt
NZ team already there and quarantining so cancellation seems less likely India doesn't perform well in UK

Interesting how the crowd is a bit more bullish on NZ than the odds would suggest. Implied probabilities devised from odds and normalizing to 100%: https://www.oddschecker.com/cricket/india-new-zealand-test-series/india-v-new-zealand/winner
Probably an unbalanced view -need to check the Indian news but these guys seem pretty confident NZ will prevail.

This isn't a mainstream test venue so there isn't a lot of past records to go on (^ tests only). India have only played two tests (2018 and 2014) and lost both to England. NZ have never played a test there.
New Zealand had an upper hand due to its better pace bowling attack and the Indian batsmen’s vulnerability against top class pace bowling on helping bowling pitches.
The toss will play a major role. The kiwis will have several significant advantages though:
Reduced the likelihood of the draw - weather issues are partly mitigated by the organisers having allowed for a reserve day

NZ loses about 1.5 times test games that it wins ( https://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283877.html ) Based on the same statistic report, near about 40% of test games end in a draw. Based on the cancellation of IPL 2020, the most recent cricket event, there is a considerable chance of the next event being delayed https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/more-sports/ipl-2021-cancelled-indian-premier-league-postponed-indefinitely-as-covid-crisis-worsens/ar-BB1glbzs
based on India win loss %in England
The cricket addict in the house assures me that if it doesn't end in a draw that NZ will win!

Both teams are strong at 2020, New Zealand won more but potential for weather to favour either side means its's close. New Zealand may have greater match fitness... Draws are rare in 2020. I assume in this forecast we are talking Men's cricket rather than REAL cricket which these days is played by India's women? :-)
New Zealand played India twice and won both. So New Zealand should have a higher chance of winning

India top ranked team in the world and they won last series at home to England. last match between these two finalists was a low coring 2 match series in NZ in Feb 2020 - NZ won 2-0. Last time India played IN England was August 2018 when England won 4-1 - will India travel better this time? Prestigious match so they'll have the pitch fit to continue for 5 days. English weather may force a draw
NZ win in NZ, India in India, playing in UK so neither side particularly favoured. may get postponed due to covid

I'll admit my ignorance when it comes to cricket. All the sports statistics look like noise to me, and without learning more, I'm going to base my initial forecast naively on population size and enthusiasm for the sport. India has more players to draw from, and cricket is considered the number one sport in India. New Zealand appears to favor rugby over cricket and has fewer players to throw at the sport. That's it. Maybe I'll learn the rules someday :)
TAB odds say India, Pitch should suit NZ, could covid cancel it? draw in only 1 of 10 recent games. Will reduce the cancelled once the indian team are in UK
Looking at the current performances, especially, Team India's performance in overseas conditions definitely gives them an advanatge.

The neutral venue makes this tricky - much easier to predict the result in either NZ or India! (home team). England conditions are usually closer to those in NZ and the last England-India series in England was 4-1 to England (c.f. last England-NZ series in England was 1-1). Worth also remembering that this is played in June which is still early in the English summer, so unlikely that pitches will be particularly dry (i.e. India-like). That factor also means I tend to weigh the chance of a weather-effected draw fairly highly. And certainly can't discount real potential for covid-disruption, with new variants emerging. Really need to guard against wishful thinking on this one...

Over the last ten years or so, NZ usually beats India when the game is played in NZ and vice versa. This match will be played in England, which is more like NZ conditions. Depending on the how the groundskeepers prepare the pitch! The 30% for postponement is to allow for COVID19 to affect either the Indian team or the England hosts. This does seem fairly likely, given IPL recently abandoned.

Pretty even - found nothing yet to say one team is better than the other. NZ historically seems to struggle to put away the cricket finals so given them a lower chance. Rain unlikely to affect game for long periods, but some lost of time could occur. Wicket seems to produce results so chance of a draw lower than normal. Covid restrictions still may be an issue, particularly if the India variant in the UK spreads
(Disclaimer - I am not a hugely devout cricket fan, but my husband is so I have picked up all this information over the years!).
Cricket... never heard of that game.

This is very tough to call. Both sides have superb seam bowling attacks, each boast one of the best batsmen of this era (Kohli and Williamson). The fact this is a one off match means there is less opportunity for a side to recover from a bad day (e.g. 36 all out). I make NZ slight favourites, but only slight. India were badly mauled in a 2 test series in NZ last year, and they represent the closest conditions to English conditions. India won in Australia earlier in the year, despite one or two poor batting performances. However, New Zealand are already in England, and plan against England before this one-off game which means they will be battle hardened, and will be playing competitive cricket whilst the Indian team are in lockdown. The corollary is they may be jaded after two games against England - especially if the pitches are flat and the bowlers are forced to bowl a lot of overs (no laughing please - I realise England's batting is fragile).
Finally a cricket question! This is the perfect sport for forecasting as so many weird things can happen.

New Zealand players already in UK and in quarantine mid-May. India players and family in a hard biobubble in India, plus will have 2 weeks quarantine in the UK ahead of playing. Will impact on training I think. As a result, NZ will be better prepared and the English conditions will favour their bowlers. Few test matches go to a draw these days (faster scoring rates) but the english weather might play a part - although an extra reserve day has been included in event of rain.

NZ are playing England which will help with preparation. India spinners less threatening than NZ swing bowlers imo; Southampton not really known as a big turner of a pitch. NZ performances against Eng will help with updating. Indian variant a legit risk to this even happening.
